name: Science and Society in Britain, 1600-1800
description: Interrogates British landmarks of the Scientific Revolution and Enlightenment in their intellectual, religious, cultural and social contexts.  Addresses canonical "achievements" in astronomy, physics and chemistry but deals equally with popular "pseudo" sciences like astrology and mesmerism.  Deconstructs progress narratives and paradigms of knowledge acquisition in Britain and its imperial world.  Investigates connections (or lack of them) between elite and popular culture.  Do not register for this seminar without at least one of the pre-requisites because this course deals extensively with mentalités of the pre-modern world.
